results.title: Jacinda Ardern resigns
results.brief_description: New Zealand PM Jacinda Adern announced her resignation today. Asked how she would like New Zealanders to remember her leadership, Ardern said “as someone who always tried to be kind.” Adern became a globally recognised figure for her progressive attitudes and empathic style but her govenment is facing low poling figures at home.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern announced her resignation today. Asked how she would like New Zealanders to remember her leadership, Ardern said “as someone who always tried to be kind.” Ardern became a globally recognised figure for her progressive attitudes and empathic style but her government is facing low polling figures at home. Actor Sam Neill expressed the view of many, tweeting, “Her treatment, the pile on, in the last few months has been disgraceful and embarrassing. All the bullies, the misogynists, the aggrieved. She deserved so much better.”
description_for_label: New Zealand PM Jacinda Ardern announced her resignation today. Asked how she would like New Zealanders to remember her leadership, Ardern said “as someone who always tried to be kind.” Ardern became a globally recognised figure for her progressive attitudes and empathic style but her government is facing low polling figures at home. Actor Sam Neill expressed the view of many, tweeting, “Her treatment, the pile on, in the last few months has been disgraceful and embarrassing. All the bullies, the misogynists, the aggrieved. She deserved so much better.”

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: DIGGERMODE
results.brief_description:
“Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction and storage, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind-the-servers look into how memory works within platform capitalism.”

“DIGGERMODE” questions the social and environmental ethics of technology in constructing, storing and sharing our images, whether in surveillance databases, museum archives or online. With artificial intelligence (AI), Joel Sherwood Spring has created landscapes in the style of acclaimed Arrernte artist Albert Namatjira being torn apart by mining machinery, and has trained another AI to answer questions like “Who’s your Mob?” Presumably, anyone could do this – but should anyone be able to appropriate Indigenous art from the internet? How do we protect our knowledges in digital spaces? Can sand used to make silicon microchips contain memories of Country?

Joel’s work confronts the viewer with uncomfortable and overlooked aspects of our hyper-networked age, grounding the possibilities of ‘the cloud’ and AI in the broader context of ongoing colonisation. The work considers the environmental damage caused by new technology and data storage, and how it is Indigenous peoples whose lands and ways of being are profoundly impacted by capitalism’s extractive processes.

constellations_primary.name: Extraction
constellations_primary.description: Tracing the material and cultural implications of extraction, DIGGERMODE is a generative behind the scenes investigates how memory works within platform capitalism.

constellations_other.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_other.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

results.title: Grace Tame visits the Prime Minister
results.brief_description: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. In this footage captured by Channel 7 cameraperson Pete Wilkinson during her visit to Government House, Tame made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

Meanwhile, a huge swath of the internet came out in support of Tame’s directness – with stills from the footage shared across social media – likening her demeanour to their feelings towards the Coalition government.

Throughout her tenure as Australian of the Year, Tame has been vocal about the government’s handling of sexual abuse allegations and its treatment of survivors. In April of 2021, when asked about Scott Morrison’s ‘as a father’ response to rape allegations made by Brittany Higgins – which some believe he didn’t take seriously until “viewing it from the lens of being a father of daughters” – Tame responded: “It shouldn’t take children to have a conscience. And actually, on top of that, having children doesn’t guarantee a conscience.” Like this most recent interaction with the Prime Minister, that clip also went viral on the internet, helping solidify Tame’s position as a courageous advocate for sexual assault survivors and a moral champion at a time when many see Australia’s leaders as lacking both courage and morals.

As Imogen Champagne writes in Crikey:, “Conservatives have been trying to silence Grace Tame all year. Now she’s finally given them silence and they can’t shut up about it.”
description_for_label: You’d be hard pressed to find a woman who hasn’t been told to smile when she obviously doesn’t want to. Patriarchal systems value women who behave, smooth things over and keep the peace – and some seem genuinely shocked when women buck the trend. Enter 2021 Australian of the Year Grace Tame. At her recent visit to Government House, she made her feelings towards Scott Morrison clear by appearing stony faced and giving the Prime Minister side-eye during a photo op, which sent conservatives into a frenzy in op-eds and on-air. If only they were as vocal about women’s rights. Maybe they just need to smile more.

results.title: Louder than words
results.brief_description: A documentary about contemporary performance poetry featuring the work of Melbourne poets Ania Walwicz, Eric Beach and Jas H. Duke. They perform in their own exuberant, idiosyncratic and sometimes bizarre way a selection of their own works.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Deborah Nadoolman Landis interview
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Professor Deborah Nadoolman Landis, an Oscar nominated Hollywood costume designer (‘Raiders of the Lost Ark’, ‘Blues Brothers’, Michael Jackson’s ‘Thriller’) is the author of ‘Hollywood Costume’ (2012), the prize-winning catalogue for the exhibition, and ‘Hollywood Sketchbook: A Century of Costume Illustration’ (2012) among many other volumes. Landis received her Ph.D. from the Royal College of Art in London and is the Founding Director of the David C. Copley Center for Costume Design at the UCLA School of Theater, Film and Television.
In this interview she talks about the origins of the Hollywood Costume industry, working as a costume designer, what a costume designer does and the relationship between the director and the costume designer.

results.title: The Ties that bind
results.creator_credit: Milad Bardan, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It took seven years after the death of his mother and a political assassination in his birth country of Lebanon before Milad really got to know his father. This is a tribute to that man.

results.title: DreamWorks Animation Masterclass: Jason Schleifer
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Shelley Matulick, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
At the heart of DreamWorks Animation is the desire to tell great stories and inspire audiences.

In a series of masterclass sessions, the creative team behind the studio that brought us ‘Kung Fu Panda’, ‘Shrek’ and ‘Madagascar’, gave an exclusive look inside the professional animation industry.

Jason Schleifer served as Head of Character Animation on DreamWorks Animation’s most recent feature, ‘Mr. Peabody & Sherman’, and has worked on numerous other key titles for the studio including ‘Megamind’, ‘Madagascar’, ‘Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa’, ‘Over the Hedge’ and ‘Shrek the Third’.

Prior to his career at DreamWorks, Schleifer had extensive involvement at Weta Digital, beginning as a Creature Technical Director and later promoted to an Animation Lead while making the ‘Lord of the Rings’ Trilogy.

results.title: Ron Magliozzi and Jenny He interview: 'Tim Burton: The Exhibition'
results.brief_description: Jenny He (Curatorial Assistant, Department of Film) and Ron Magliozzi (Assistant Curator, Department of Film) are co-organizers of the Tim Burton exhibition, from MoMa (The Museum of Modern Art) in New York. Here they are interviewed by Kate Warren, ACMI’s Assistant Curator, about their work on ‘Tim Burton: The Exhibition’. They take us through the process, from inception, through to collaborating with Tim Burton, of Burton’s work and the curatorial process. As well as viewing Tim Burton’s work from an artistic perspective, we also gain insight into the art of the curator and curatorial perspective.

results.title: An Evening with Shaun Tan
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
To celebrate the exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From Book to Film’ a special evening with the Oscar®-winning animator, author and illustrator, Shaun Tan was held on 24 July 2013. He discussed the making of the exhibition, talked about his body of work and shared insights into his creative processes.
Shaun’s books, including ‘The Rabbits’, ‘The Red Tree’ and the acclaimed graphic novel ‘The Arrival’, have been widely translated and enjoyed by readers of all ages. His work as a feature film concept artist can be seen in films like ‘Wall-E’ (2008) and his Academy Award®-winning animated short ‘The Lost Thing’, which he also wrote and co-directed.
In 2011, Shaun received the prestigious Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award in Sweden. His attraction to children’s stories with confronting or puzzling ideas is reflected in his work, which encourages dialogue between adult readers and younger listeners.
